Vancouver, WA 9/29/2011 Brothers is a counter-service joint that charges like a sit-down brewpub. My husband and I went on our lunch break and were puzzled by the contrast between the atmosphere and the pricing. To be sure, it's a very nice new establishment, but not the kind of place where you expect to drop $9 on a burger (ie. my husband's Hickory burger). The basic burger will cost around $5, but once you add cheese and fries, it'll cost you closer to $7.
I wish I could rate Brothers higher because they do make a pretty tasty burger. My husband was raving about the perfect onion ring on his. We got good service as well. But for the price and the atmosphere, I just can't imagine going back. It's too casual to qualify for a date night at that price, and way too expensive for counter-service lunch, especially with Five Guys just around the corner. Sorry, Brothers.

Minus 1 star for the ordering/serving set up -- order/pay at the counter, and then a (usually pretty attentive) server delivers your drinks/food/drink refills. For those of us that pay with plastic, the opportunity to tip our server has passed and then you feel guilty for not tipping the poor waiter/waitress if you are so inclined!
Plus .5 star for decent drinking water. Ambiance is OK, leans more towards being a sports bar I think.
So overall rating ends up at 2.5.We used to live closer and went in probably 4 or 5 times since it opened, but we moved a couple of months ago, and it's not a place we'd make a special trip back for.

Vancouver, WA 8/12/2011 Hmmph...well, I wanted to like this place. I thought it was cute and comfortable and our server was super friendly and overall the staff was pretty nice.
Definitely could tell that the place was newly opened. The cashier/order taker was new and not exactly sure how to place orders/charge for a side of fruit or ring up a kids meal, but she figured it out and it was fairly painless.
So you walk in, place your order at the counter, get a number and find a seat. I found it pretty simple and self-explanatory but glimpsing over other reviews, I guess this concept is not overly familiar for all.
I thought the space was cute and welcoming. There is a decent outdoor space too. We sat inside and were promptly attended to by our server who quickly brought our drinks (two blue moons and a kids' milk) and then brought our food. No problems with the service.
I had the black and blue burger. Really, meh. Hated the sauce on it and the sauce was way too much. What a mess The burger lacked any serious flavor and just did not excite. Had a side of tater tots, and they were just not good. Either I do not like tater tots anymore or these were lacking some serious tater tot flavor. Overall, my food choices were bland, bland, bland. The blue moon, however, was delicious and served with the appropriate orange wedge.
Kid had the slider with cheese and a side of fruit (I think we have the one kid in the US who hates potatoes/fries/tater tots). He chowed the slider. It came with ketchup on it, although I do not remember reading that it would, but luckily he liked the ketchup. I was worried at first that the burger would go uneaten. The serving was probably just the right size for my toddler. Any kid over 3 will be left hungry. The side of fruit was pretty gross. It was way too sweet, like it was candied. Definitely from frozen.
So one little slider later, and a nose up at the candied fruit and complete disdain for a tater tot, he was looking around the table still hungry. We got our server's attention and asked if it would be possible to get some yogurt for the kid, even though it was not breakfast hours. She made it happen and brought it over. Kiddie really enjoyed the strawberry yogurt and was finally feeling full.
Total hats off for that service!!! Outstanding and really great! :)
My guy had the standard cheeseburger with bacon, side of fruit (yea, he's not a fry guy either....guess that's where our son gets it from). He did not have much to say about his burger and the only thing he had to say about the fruit was, 'it's not good'.
Overall, I found the place cute, comfortable, good beer, great service. But the food was so bland and forgettable.
It was 40 bucks for two burgers, a side of fruit, tater tots, kids meal (slider, fruit, milk) and two large blue moons.
meh.....

Vancouver, WA 8/1/2011 We went to Brother's at lunch today. My thought for this place is, "Mixed Metaphor". From what I saw on the web site, I was expecting something like Fuddruckers. What I got was something not like that at all.
The initial walk up and order was much like 5 Guys (place your order at a walk-up counter, pay, receive an order number), yet they have waitress service. Here is where the mixed part comes in. The folks that bring out your food are not the people who you ordered your food from. This design ensures every order is bungled in some way. When your food does come out, the person bringing your food has to wander all over the seating area looking for a little card with your order number on it, which you've hopefully displayed clearly on your table. In addition, a different waitress brings your food out each time it's prepared. During our time there, we were offered food which we didn't order no less than twice by two different waitresses, so that by the time our food did finally arrive we weren't at all sure that it was our correct order either.
A better serving model would be for the waitresses to have turf, instead of wandering from table to table looking for something to do. The current model is better suited if the employees were the Looney Toons Tasmanian Devil.
Then the person who is your waitress (but who is not *your* waitress, apparently), to make note of what numbers are present on their turf and keep on the look out for those orders coming up. Just like a normal restaurant.
Overall the service process is a fingernail on chalkboard experience in how to do something inefficiently without any visible benefits. They should either go with the total self-service model of 5 Guys or the full waitress service model of Red Robin. As Yoda would say, Serve or serve not there is no half way.
Okay, the service process issues can all be fixed with the process changes, now onto the food.
The only thing that was even close to Fuddruckers was the bun, and that seemed a bit on the dry/stale side. The burger itself was nothing special in flavor or texture. The toppings while fresh and tasty were completely and utterly beat down by the use of the "Brother's sauce". This is a closely resemblance of Thousand Island dressing, but only if you got it at Chuck-E-Cheese. The sauce is cloying sweet. I do not expect nor desire a sugar burger.
Unless this restaurant makes some major changes in food, ingredient quality (Read stale bun), and makes a case that distinguishes it from 5 Guys, Red Robin, Fuddruckers, or the Vancouver local place: Burger Bungalow. I don't see any reason to go there. Especially since there is a 5 guys about 2 blocks from there.

Hartford, CT Updated - 7/16/2011 Went back on their Day 2 and tried their Brothers Cheeseburger (with Tillamook Cheddar - but they have lots of other choices). The burger was great! The patty was juice and cooked medium - not over cooked (which a certain other brother owned established with locations throughout OR&WA, including prime real estate down on the Columbia River, does on a regular basis); the burger is made of ground chuck, which as a good fat content to keep the burger flavorful and juicy. The veggies (lettuce, tomato, red onion) were fresh and flavorful - lettuce was crisp, tomatoes taste like tomatoes. The fries, cut from fresh potatoes with the skins still attached, were good and not greasy; they are fried in "clear liquid soy shortening," which I was told is trans fat free. For those concerned about GMO, the soy is probably GMO, as almost all non-organic soy is GMO.
Service was attentive and helpful. The wait for the burgers was at the most 5 minutes, which I thought was pretty good.
The only negative to the meal was the pickle spear that accompanied the burger. I'm a Claussen pickle kinda gal, and these definitely were not Claussen. They were crisp, but they had a chemical-like taste with a metalically after taste. Nasty! But I won't knock points off for that little detail. I did talk with one of the brothers about it. Hopefully they will find a new supplier for some good pickles.
Burger patties are 1/3 pound, and prices start at $5.99. Burgers are a la carte (well, they come with that nasty pickle spear). Fries are $2.39 (I think - give or take 10 cents), but you can add fries to your burger for $1.89. They also offer 2 oz. sliders individually or as a trio. For those not a fan of beef, they also offer turkey (forgot to ask about the source of the poultry) and veggie patties, a grilled chicken breast sandwich, and grilled cheese. A BLT is also on the menu. Three salads are also offered: Ceaser, and Iceberg Wedge with bacon (and blue cheese, I think), and a Spinach Salad with some bacon and other stuff (I was mesmerized by the word bacon so I didn't pay much attention to anything else). Milk shakes are available, and sodas are from Coca Cola. Oh, and they have a selection of local beers (and I'm assuming wine).
Mmmm.... Maybe I'll go back for Day 3 and get some sliders......

Brothers 19206 SE 1st Street Suite 102 Camas, WA 98607 360-718-2919 http://brothersburgers.c…
First off this place is better than Five Guys for when you want food with real flavor that is not swimming in grease.
Today the owners were on the premises and the restaurant crew was ambulated while the business has almost found its sea legs. Once they find their Zen state, everything will likely find a comfortable harmony.
The restaurant is a first rate design with inside, outside and to go dining. You place your order at the counter, take a small folder with your number inserted at the end, sit down at the table or counter of your choice, and a server brings your food to the table. In the center of each table is an assortment of condiments and napkins. It would be nice if they add some malt vinegar for the fried potatoes.
The plate was nicely put together with the Black&Blue Gorgonzola Burger that included a perfect combination of vegetables on a quality bun for $7.69. Included were a side of fries on the plate for $1.89, which was more than enough and asked two others at the table to help me finish. A full order of fries cost more. Also on the plate was a big slice of pickle to round out the meal. The drink glasses are very large and servers offer frequent refills.
Coming from a generation that enjoyed blackened foods without freaking out like some do today, the flavor of the burger was right on. However, if I could make one suggestion, I'd like to have that same exterior while keeping the interior medium at the center.
There was a time when we enjoyed eating raw high quality beef with salt and garlic, which still speaks to my inner-cannibal, but I'd never risk it with the factory farming methods of today.
We will definitely return again.
Eat life before life eats you; Mazel a presto!

Vancouver, WA 7/24/2011 Okay, I'm going to be brutally honest here. We waited quite awhile for this place to open, went twice after it was supposed to be open only to see signs saying "closed for private party". Third try we actually got in. Confusing is the first word. Line up, don't line up? Sit down, wait to be seated?? After some urging from the counter girl we made our approach. We ordered The Hickory, Black&Blue, onion rings, fries and chocolate and vanilla shake (for the kids), and two soft drinks.
1)Drinks were unnecessarily huge and pricey, almost 4 bucks for 2...I was never asked a size preference and assumed I was getting the smallest they had since I said "small drink". Nope 2)Both kids (who are no foodies!) complained the shakes tasted "funny". Youngest son refused to drink his chocolate after a few sips. These shakes were 4 each!!! (one again I asked for smalls and was sold the adult size I guess). 3)The Hickory burger was a nice idea but not executed well. Large dollop of bbq sauce in the middle, no other sauce of any kind on this incredibly dry burger. 4)Meat patties have no flavor at all and are extremely overcooked. I have had a juicer patty at Sonic, for goodness sake. 5)Brioche bun is nice but seems a bit too much of a stretch here. Husband complained that it was too much "dough" to get through. If meat was juicier it would be nice to have the brioche to soak some of that up and give you a delivery system, but no luck. 7)Fries and onion rings are not very well done. Rings are too thick...no one wants to chew on a half of an onion, and the fries taste frozen and reheated. Even tried the rosemary/parm fry for flavor and wasn't impressed. 8)Wait staff...do they want to be a restaurant or fast food? Make up your mind! The endless cruising of the staff was irritating and unnecessary. Why are you wasting your profits on this gimmick???? Ours was friendly but the drink waitress was an idiot who walked past us twice with our drinks. I did not feel compelled to leave a tip. 9)What's with the breakfast menu? Shouldn't you just concentrate on making a fantastic burger???
Bottom line for $40 (and this includes 2 kids who ate nothing but a shake), this is WAY OVERPRICED and just not worth the money.

Vancouver, WA 9/19/2011 We went to Brother's Burgers on a date night recently. Thought I'd share with you our experience.
Two and half stars if I were able, not so bad as meh, but not A-OK either.
Brother's Burgers seems to be a restaurant that can't decide if it is fast food or a full on sit down restaurant. Why do I say this? You walk through the doors to a nicely appointed, not overly ostentatious setting. The tones are warm and inviting, the gas fire place a nice touch, especially as it was raining on this particular evening. It has the feel of a Starbucks. As you walk through the doors, you are greeted by an ordering counter. You look at the board, select your meal of choice and pay the lady. I didn't include a tip, because this type of setup is typical of a fast food restaurant, and who tips at a Burgerville or 5 guys? They offer beer and wine with your meal, and not just cheep beer, but fine local selections for a price. I paid 5 dollars for a large Mirror Pond to round out my custom "made to order" meal complete with rosemary fries. Then you sit down at a table and wait for the food to be brought out to you. The meal was decent, my wife order the Hickory burger and very much enjoyed it. She ordered a side salad and was a bit disappointed to see a pile of lettuce, two tomato wedges and two slices of cucumber. I'm not a salad guy, but apparently, for the price, there should have been more to it. 27 dollars for two burgers, an order of fries, a side salad and a beer is a tad steep, especially if you're under the impression you are eating at a fast food restaurant. A waitress appeared, brought us our food, returned to ask if everything was alright, and would have received a tip had I not been traveling with debit card only. Over all it was not bad, but not memorable either.
Here's the thing; you have 5 Guys, who are expensive, but tasty fast food. Then you have Red Robin, also expensive, but it's a sit down, full on restaurant. Each restaurant knows where they are in the market place and delivers accordingly. My recommendation to Brother's, decide where you want to be and go for it. You can't be effect in the middle. The guests are confused and your wait staff is going to leave for a place where they actually get consistent tips. Would we go again? Maybe, depending on the mood. It's quieter than a red robin, so a nicer atmosphere for a date and I'd probably give their burgers another try.
A few thoughts for the owners if you happen to read these reviews: Buy pre-wrapped straws. The waitress came to the table with our water glasses and placed the unwrapped straw on the table. That is the equivalent of having me lick the table before drinking my glass of water. I commented on this to my wife. She said maybe the waitress could have just put the straw into the glass before serving it and that would have been better. At that moment we witnessed the girl behind the counter unpacking a gross of straws, placing them in a container and then packing them down by placing her hand on the top and mashing down. What's the big deal you ask? Whatever germs were on her hand are now on the drinking end of all those straws. That's the equivalent of me licking the palm of her hand before taking a drink. No thanks!
Second, have the walk up order counter only for those ordering food to go. You have a nice restaurant, a cool vibe. Maximize it. Have customers sit down, order from a waiter or waitress and feel like they are at a true sit down meal. The wait staff will be rewarded with tips, the customers won't have to stand in line to order their dinner and the whole experience will be more enjoyable.
Third, season the beef. The hamburger I custom ordered had bun, beef, Tillamook cheddar pickles, tomatoes, and a fried egg on it. I couldn't tell if it had sauce, mayonnaise, or ketchup on it. But the over taste was bland. With all those tasty ingredients, bland should have been the last thing I was tasted. A chef seasons the food to taste before sending it out the door to the dinners. Take a page from their book and do likewise with your burgers.
Lastly, invest in thicker napkins. Your burgers are juicy. I went through at least 9 napkins. It might be a cost savings method to get the thinner/ cheaper ones, but your whole atmosphere speaks to quality. Get a thicker napkin to complete the message.
Best of luck, I'm a big fan of local businesses and truly hope you succeed.
